title: Which toy will win the Innovative Toy of the Year Award for 2016?
possible_answers: Star Wars Science - Jedi Force Levitator
preds:
* crosses fingers * 
* says a prayer *
* turn in the right direction *
*clicks heals*
*rings a tiny bell*
*close my eyes*
*pushes submit*
and waits....

First, I gave scores to each toys based on the award criteria mentioned on the website. 
Creativity
Originality
Innovation
Design
Promotion
Excellence
Marketplace Acceptance (OPTIONAL)
Then I mapped the scores out of 100 for each criterion to the importance to the percentages allocated to voter community. 
Members of Toy Industry Association	30%
Retailers Mass	15%
Retailers Specialty	15%
Journalists	10%
Bloggers	10%
Consumers 	20%
The outcome was the average of the score based on my view of the criteria and past history along with the score based on the voter community score.

**The crowd is way off on this one! It is pretty simple to build a Bayesian model for this question that factors in real data. The real data predicts a result much different than what is being forecasted now.** To start, I looked at toys that won in the past, removed any toys that previous results would likely disqualify, and focused my model on the follow 4 toys that I believe are realistic contenders: 1. i-Loom 
2. Makey Makey 
3. MeccaNoid G15 
4. Jedi Levitator The contest rules tell us exactly how to weight each voting group in a Bayesian model: "Five weighted ballots – one each for consumers (25%), mass and specialty retailers (40% combined), journalists and bloggers (20%), and members of the Toy Industry Association (15%) – were open from November 17, 2015 through January 17, 2016. Winners will be announced during a formal presentation ceremony on February 12, 2016" With the weightings set, we just need to find proxy data to estimate the voting of each group. For each voting group I used the following metrics as proxies to estimate the voting behavior of each group: **Note: I used Amazon reviews as a proxy for total sales. In addition, I assumed that retailers and the toy industry would vote in their best interests by voting for the toy that they make the most money from.** 1. Consumers - Good Judgement forecasts and Number of Amazon Reviews (weighted 50-50)
2. Journalists and Bloggers- # of news articles published 
3. Retailers - # of Amazon reviews X Estimated Profit Margin 
4. Toy Industry - # of Amazon reviews total X Estimated Profit Margin Using the contest’s weightings and my proxy data, my model gives the following forecast: 1. i-Loom – 4% 
2. Makey Makey – 31% 
3. MeccaNoid G15 – 53% 
4. Jedi Levitator – 12%

Winners will be announced during a formal presentation ceremony on February 12, 2016" With the weightings set, we just need to find proxy data to estimate the voting of each group. 3. Retailers - # of Amazon reviews X Estimated Profit Margin 
4. Toy Industry - # of Amazon reviews total X Estimated Profit Margin  Using the contest’s weightings and my proxy data, my model gives the following forecast: 1. i-Loom – 4%
2. Makey Makey – 34%
3. MeccaNoid G15 – 56%
4. Jedi Levitator – 6%

Does anyone have an actual rationale for which toy will win TOMORROW? !!   I read the "sweepstakes" policy to determine how the winner will be determined:  No dice
http://www.toyawards.org/toyaward/The_Sweepstakes/toyaward/Rules.aspx?hkey=db76f74b-677b-4d75-bb2a-e0cac4a68bf0 The homepage says: "finalists have been nominated from within the industry and are being voted on by toy companies, toy retailers, and consumers (you!)."  The "you!" part is simply a consumer choice award across all 12 categories so I'll assume these are retailers and toy companies.  Anyone know the sales figures or margins for these things?

Consumers 20%
Journalists and bloggers 20%
Retailers (mass + specialty*) 30%
Members of the Toy Industry Association 30%

Looking back at previous winners I realized I'd bought really innovative toys for my children and the 2012 winner.  Confirmation that I rock : )
this is what desperation looks like  : /

I very reluctantly and probably regrettable re-calibrated my propensity based on @lilolvvorn  analysis.  I don't like the Star War's Levitator toy but it's difficult to bet against the favorite.  That said, it's easy to expect star wars popularity driving  sales and that's a pretty important indicator for judging novel toys -- market acceptance.   final analysis - I have no idea, having kids isn't the advantage I thought it was, and therefore I regret getting into this question

I'm  sorry  but whoever is forecasting Maccanoid to win  - how do you account for the TOP questions on amazon.com? Question: Spent 7 hours building, put brand new batteries in and it starts telling us the batteries are low almost immediately. Did we do something wrong? Answer: My husband spent 8 hours building and my daughter played with her meccano for about 2 hours and had to replace the batteries! I was shocked as well...so no you didn't do anything wrong, unless we did as well! 
By Francela Valdez on December 28, 2015 Question: How long do the c batteries power the robot? One of the reviews mentions that the batteries only last fifteen minutes. Answer: Our brand new batteries lasted about 15 minutes. I've emailed Meccano asking for battery recommendations.  -- Makey Makey reviews are 75%  5  FREAKING  STARS on amazon.com and the reviews are like, "Wow I had no idea how awesome this was going to be until my children started playing with it and there's no limit to the cool things you can do." I don't get it  :(
I think I really fucked up on this question and I have no idea how to fix it, good times  : )

With limited time, I mostly considered TOTY's industry role as industry gatekeeper and promoter in context of past awards, recent global toy market value, toy market global growth directions as "outside" factors.  Similarity to past top 3 TOTY awards would seem to eliminate a few of the candidates from even placing (in my mind) (loom) i-loom (2014 WINNER: Rainbow Loom® by Choon’s Design LLC), (Cruis) Flipsies™ Sandy's House & Ocean Cruiser (2013 WINNER: LEGO® Friends by The LEGO Group), (MiP) MiPosaur (2015 WINNER: ZOOMER DINO™ by SPIN MASTER). (Maze) Laser Maze™ Jr. looks very cool and innovative, but it's "laser" tech seems out of sync with the climate of the popular imagination to be the winner; it's likely to be an enthusiasts favorite, and despite it's likely appeal in Russia (based on "Science" and "Construction" attributes that seem to drive that market), Russia doesn't seem to be predicted as a large toy growth market. (Yes I found that same slideshare Euromonitor report that many of you probably did--if only there were more time lol) 3 Toys stood out to me:  3rd Choice:
(Jedi) Star Wars Science - Jedi Force Levitator which undoubtedly gets a big boost by the recent box office success of Star Wars, including in a key future global toy growth market, China. That said, the video describing the tech behind it made me think it's going to be more of an enthusiasts thing; after watching kids play with it, the play experience seems a bit wonky and "the force" is a pretty abstract selling point, and the likeness to the light-saber (the way it is used in the movies) is limited. Furthermore, the niche oddity of this toy is likely one of the many reasons it was not part of the large integrated marketing push promoting things like BB-8 App-Enabled Droid by Sphero - Star Wars: The Force Awakens which closely resembles the Droid in the new film.  Made by Uncle Milton only featured on the Star Wars "Science" niche pages, and not promoted or sold on Disney Star Wars page, or apparently visible on the Disney Star Wars products page (a search for "Star Wars Levitator" yielded nothing). Therefore, I discount the benefit of Disney marketing and promotions and Star Wars fame for this product.  2nd Choice:
(Makey) Makey Makey Classic I like because of its USB interoperability, the intuitiveness of play (invention!), and because it reminds me of the massive historical successes of video games that have incredibly low system requirements and good playability, and how it offers at least the possibility of introducing users to a wider online community. It's also really a platform, it's infinite possibilities make this a versatile "toy" or "tool" that can keep on giving as well as be a good entry point into circuitry, programming, and invention. "Makey Makey Classic" search on Youtube gives 616 results, many of which are weird inventions people have made, it's quite impressive a social media showing especially considering that a "Star Wars Levitator" Youtube search gives 1200 results, most of which are official promos and other unrelated "Star Wars" search results--it seems like the oddity of the "Makey Makey Classic" name means that it has already captured people's imagination and has earned it's results organically vs. paid hits from Disney on the levitator. This is the toy that should win, but I don't think it will. It's dependent on a computer ($$$ & knowledge of other software) and the $50 price tag versus the low-budget marketing that seems to rely on a few gimmicky examples (bananas)  and more on the inventor's MIT cachet rather than really thinking about how it fits into user experiences; people seeing the promo, might not understand why this thing is the coolest of the toys on the list, and think $50 is a bit too much for a bananna piano. Makey Makey may take a long time to organically grow and achieve it's full potential, there's too much uncertainty in the future to say it's a winner.  In addition to being a good gateway to the Arduino hobbyist culture, as well as programming, and invention in general, I like this because it's likely to be something parents would do with their kids, which leads me to my next top choice.  First Choice:
(G15) Meccanoid G15 has a high price-point, but seems to work well across many dimensions. It's a science and technology based toy that seems like a platform (changeability/ versatility of use, and cross/up  selling opportunities for the company) for launching kids and their parents into the world of robotics, machine language, programming etc. Furthermore, the time seems right considering the current "sci-fi"obsession with artificial intelligence and robotics that is evidenced across many aspects of popular culture. The relatively mature marketing and robust distribution (e.g. Toys R Us, Walmart, Amazon) gives examples of how this toy fits into a home discovery and invention experience, and the toy is readily available in the channel. The toy has already made a large social impact as is evidenced by the over 4000 Youtube video search results, many of which are user generated content. This toy, if marketed poorly, could appear to be a niche-nerd market thing, but they've done a good job of integrating into lifestyles and play experiences. Things that are a platform for discovery need to provide surprises, but need predictable formats for discovery (this toy feels like a toy, not an arduino board with a lot of wires, it's easy to imagine getting into this play experience). The Makey Makey seems too far out ahead of the market, The Meccanoid G15 seems like it fits in the current market and can grow it/ take it forward. Other macro factors (from the Euromonitor report) "Construction and Dolls to give growth in absolute terms" make a compelling case for this toy as a winner.   Since the question asks to pick a winner, I'm essentially putting most of eggs in one basket, feels a bit more likely gambling, I'm guessing this is a novice mistake; I identified other dimensions of analysis that I initially wanted to follow up on (below), but with the deadline approaching I am just doing this in one evening.  Thanks for a question that seems like a playful entry-point to learn something about forecasting that I won't care too much about how off I am :-) If I had more time I would have considered the following more deeply:
-Targetable market, expected penetration (existing nerds, cross-over users (ala wii), existing mainstream toy base)
-Play-style shift required
-Definition of innovation
-Where does toy exist on adoption curve in relevant tech/market
-Intuitiveness
-Price point & accessibility (What do you get for the price? items + access to community + introductory knowledge)
-How long does the experience last (materials, play-experience, post-purchase engagement, communities)
-Applications (play/productivity)
-In line with future/ capture public imagination
-Likelyhood of purchase/ purchase ocassions
-TOTY's industry role (identify creativity re: toys--impact, innovation, change and guide market, change play behavior, change perspectives on (e.g. robots, AI) 2/7/16 Forecasts For Top 3 Picks
1) Meccanoid G15 85%
2) Makey Makey Classic 5%
3) Jedi Force Levitator 5% 2/8/16 Updates
@Doudtful Thanks for suggesting having a look at Amazon.com user ratings; 4.5 Stars is a good rating for the Makey Makey, however it's across a confirmed buyer base of 169 versus 4 Stars for Meccanoid G15 with confirmed buyer base of 209; this is itself doesn't seem very compelling, however the distribution of 5 star tier ratings is definitely higher for Makey Makey, as you mention, so it might be worth adjusting my forecast. At this point, to get some context on the Amazon data, I think it's worth considering how much weight to give to consumer feedback, and how long each product has been on the market.  To put these results in perspective and to get a view on organic desire in the market for the products I tried to find the launch dates for each toy to see how long they have been up for sale; I used Google Adwords keyword searches to see when people first started searching for each toy: Meccanoid G15 searches start to pick up July, which appears to be the launch date (I also found a Barnes & Noble product listing dated 7/13/15) so let's say that it became available in July 2015; Google Adwords shows "Meccanoid G15" searches at July 110, August 590, Sept 1000, Oct 3600, Nov 14,800, and Dec. 27100 with average monthly at 3600 searches. What seems impressive about this is the early geometric growth so soon after launch, however this seems discounted by the fact that Dec is Christmas and that I suspect all toys get a boost here; we would really need to see Jan and Feb 2016 data for a better perspective. Makey Makey's Google Adwords search data seems quite impressive: from January 2015 all the way through October there has been steady search volume of at least 12,000 and several months with up to 14K, then in November 30K searches and December 40K searches; based solely on the Google Adwords searches it seems Makey Makey has really taken hold of the market curiosity in a lasting way.  The next question is, how does this translate into sales figures, and how much do sales figures impact on TOTY's criteria for innovation. The consistent market buzz for Makey Makey seems less impressive against the Amazon.com data considering that it has been available, most likely since before January 2015, with only 169 sold in that time (however, it is entirely possible that the Amazon listing was renewed at some point and this is not total Amazon data); furthermore, if you look at the earliest date of the Amazon reviews for the Makey Makey, they go back to November 2012, which makes this toy's total sold on Amazon figure seem really unimpressive (169 over 3 years). It is very possible that most of the Makey Makey's have been sold on their direct sales website or other channels, so it's hard to know how heavily to weight the Amazon information. The Meccanoid Google Adwords search data for just a few months is quite compelling in showing a toy with exponentially growing interest online, but again it launched just before Christmas so hard to say without Jan/Feb data. Since the Meccanoid G15 keyword data very likely includes searches for Meccanoid G15 KS, the big-brother toy ( about 2.5 times as expensive as the G15), so we could discount that the G15 alone is driving this online interest alone, making it's Google data less impressive--however, from this perspective, if we add the Amazon sales totals for both G15 (209) and G15 KS (159) we might then say, with less impressive search showing, these toys are still doing better in 3-4 months than Makey Makey has done in over 3 years.  After checking TOTY competition rules, the final voting must be completed by January 15th, so the judges don't have much more data than we are talking about here.  The Adwords search made me curious, if launched in 2012, why hasn't Makey Makey been nominated or awarded yet--my guess is that it probably has, but perhaps the judges felt this toy needed a bit longer to reach market maturity, it's so unique. For comparison I looked at search results for "Star Wars bb-8" the massively marketed robot, not very impressive results, but then changed keywords to various permutations of "force awakens robot/droid/bb-8" and "star wars robot/droid/bb-8"  to and "star wars droid" shows spiking searches in Dec. up to 40K, on the level of Makey Makey; considering the Star wars search term is not necessarily specific enough to isolate searches for that toy, it seems that Makey Makey, may be having it's mainstream breakthrough now--this could be it's year. I'm gonna adjust my estimate.   2/8/16
1) Meccanoid G15 80%
2) Makey Makey 10%
3) Star Wars Levitator 6%* Due to recent media coverage citing NDP stats on Star Wars toy sales, I'm upping the marketing "draft" benefit for anything related to Star Wars, but not by much, because it is uncertain how much sales figures alone are part of this decision (certainly they at least demonstrate the toy is out there and being used). 2/10/16 Research / No Forecast Update Frustrated because I feel that the Makey Makey should be the winner based on the limited perspectives I've been able to research in 4 days; another compelling argument for the Makey Makey is the over 40K Youtube videos, many user-generated content; basically, I feel the decision comes down to whether or not the award giver HAS THE ABILITY to properly appreciate this toy's market impact. Going to focus some last minute research on whether the award giving mechanism has enough permeability and judgment to be able to appreciate the Makey Makey.  Based on past winners of innovative toy and the other nominees back through 2012, none have been as unorthodox a toy as the Makey Makey. Makey Makey being just nominated this year, says something.  In terms of the TOTY association's connection to the market, the NOMINATION process seems well connected to the real-world toy industry and the people you would expect to be able to appreciate the nuance of the Makey Makey and the clear social impact, namely children, parents, journalists/bloggers, inventors, academics, mommys and teachers.  However, the DECISION process for winners is weighted 60% in favor of RETAILERS (30%) and MEMBERS OF THE TOY INDUSTRY ASSOCIATION (30%) versus  40% for most of those people mentioned in the nomination process.   SELECTION OF FINALISTS (NOMINATIONS)
 (http://www.toyassociation.org/TIA/Events/TOTY/Nomination_and_Selection_Process/Events2/TOTY_Awards/Awards_Guidelines1.aspx?hkey=77d3db88-7058-43e9-8402-a44bf4f8ffe9#.VrtEZ1grLmE) Retail Buyers
Mass (not included for “Specialty” category)
Specialty (only for “Educational”, “Game”, “Innovative” and “Specialty” categories)
Journalists / Bloggers
National consumer magazine toy editors
Trade magazine editors
Mommy bloggers
Toy Specialists
Academia, graduate (e.g., FIT, OTIS, etc.)
Academia, practical application (e.g., preschool teacher, etc.)
Inventor (requires signed statement affirming no conflict or special interest in category) VOTING (FINAL DECISION)
 (http://www.toyassociation.org/TIA/Events/TOTY/Nomination_and_Selection_Process/Events2/TOTY_Awards/Awards_Guidelines1.aspx?hkey=77d3db88-7058-43e9-8402-a44bf4f8ffe9#.VrtEZ1grLmE) All category ballots will be weighted as follows:
Consumers 20%
Journalists and bloggers 20%
Retailers (mass + specialty*) 30%
Members of the Toy Industry Association 30% If we look at the TOTY definition of innovation for this award: "The best toy that combines the most unique blend of innovative technology and play value for children today." "Play value" seems like industry nomenclature, so found a Wikipedia entry on it, which I copy and paste in it's entirety below.   Looking at G15 and Makey Makey from the "Play Value" dimensions below, I think both do well; Makey Makey would seem to do better in the longevity aspect of play value. The one area where Makey Makey might suffer based on a play value analysis is "self-directed play" that is, it may be easy enough to rig the USB interface to work with one set of items, but more difficult with others, and it is quite easy to see that a parent's involvement might be absolutely required to get some things working. There is no doubt about the brilliance of this device, however, it might breach the boundary of toy used by these award givers, towards productivity tool.  In terms of "play value" that is integrated into the toy itself, and becomes self-evident or discoverable to a child user during play, I think the G15 still presents a more understandable choice for the industry gatekeeper status quo. Although I think the Makey Makey is brilliant, I'm not going to update my forecast, perhaps I'm not giving the 60% weight industry incumbent voters enough credit on vision.  I have a feeling that just nominating Makey Makey this year might be enough of a statement about innovation for them.  Play value
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Play value is the essential value of a toy or game for play. The term is frequently employed in the field of child development and playwork for the assessment of toys, games, equipment and spaces. When they are fun and engaging, playthings and spaces are said to have play value; those that are quickly discarded or are considered uninteresting do not. In short, objects of play must be compelling and encourage the child's involvement in order to have true play value. Play value has been defined as 'how much play can you get out of something'.[1] Classic toys are examples of toys with true play value as they continue to provide new discoveries and adventures in each subsequent session of play.[2] Contents  [hide] 
1	Assessment of play value in the selection of toys and games
2	Multiple uses
3	Self-directed play
4	Appeal to more than one age or stage of development
5	Inverse relationship with linkage to TV, movies and video games
6	Complement or supplement other play activities
7	Stay with children as they develop
8	Promote respectful interaction
9	Useful for further learning
10	References
11	See also
Assessment of play value in the selection of toys and games[edit]
The selection of toys and games has long been a concern to parents and educators. Many fail to sufficiently engage children. Stevanne Auerbach emphasizes that products should last as long as possible and have many different and long lasting uses. Good examples of toys with high play value are blocks, construction toys and yo-yos. The toy should have clear instructions so the parent and child are guided to its best use by the designer and manufacturer.[3] In playwork terms it is the child who determines the play value of an object rather than adults or instruction manuals Multiple uses[edit]
Toys tend to have high play value when they may be used, engaged and employed in manifold ways. A good example is Lego bricks which may be assembled and connected in myriad ways to make cars, trucks, planes, trains, etc. Another good example is polymer clay which may be used for sculpting hand-shaped items, such as beads, jewelry, and charms. Self-directed play[edit]
Children need to be in charge of their own play activity. According to PBS' The Whole Child Web site when adults plan the play activity and structure the outcome of playtime it is far less effective than if children have the freedom to form their own ideas, practice skills and use playthings at their own speed. Cardboard box toys are an example of playthings which allow children to use their own imaginations.[4] Appeal to more than one age or stage of development[edit]
Playability is a word that when applied to games has a similar meaning to play value. Those games with strong playability appeal to more than one age or stage of development. For example, Monopoly and Risk are two games that appeal to a wide range of ages, though generally not to very young children. Similarly, toys that appeal to more than one age or stage tend to have higher play value. Inverse relationship with linkage to TV, movies and video games[edit]
Authors Nancy Carlsson-Paige & Diane Levin[5] note that play value in toys can be seen as inversely related to their degree of linkage with TV, movies and video games. For example, G.I. Joe, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, and Power Rangers are all examples of toys that have cross-feeds with television shows that have violent themes. Similarly, Godzilla, Small Soldiers, Spawn, Jurassic Park and Starship Troopers toys are marketed to children 4 and up. Complement or supplement other play activities[edit]
Computer games or electronic toys are examples of toys that can complement or supplement other play activities. According to author Cathrine Neilsen-Hewett,[6] while often stimulating, engaging and fun, these toys should never become a substitute for traditional play activities such as drawing, pretending, or block building. Instead, electronic games are best thought of as adding to or reinforcing other kinds of play, and are not a suitable replacement for parental interaction and attention. @Doudtful some more input in case you're interested.  2/10/16 Odds and Ends Ok my issue with bumping Makey Makey chance of winning higher is not an issue with Makey Makey, but rather relates to my understanding of the TOTY judges perspective; especially considering that 60% final decision weighting is given to Retailers (30%) and organization members (30%). The awesomeness of Makey Makey is not in question, just whether the judges have the ability to appreciate it and whether it fits with their industry role agenda.  Unable to find sales figures for any of the toys specifically, I'm sort of triangulating the larger markets they might appeal to, and using each categories growth trend as a potential insight into TOTY's thinking on where the market is going.  http://www.toyassociation.org/tia/industry_facts/salesdata/industryfacts/sales_data/sales_data.aspx?hkey=6381a73a-ce46-4caf-8bc1-72b99567df1e#.VrvwPVgrLmE Judging by relevant categories to Meccanoid G15, this toy has cross-over appeal in at least 4 categories (Building Sets, Dolls, Youth Electronics, and maybe Action Figures) that compose over 34% of the existing 19.45 BN USD market; 3 of these categories, with the exclusion of Youth Electronics with negative growth 2014/15, have demonstrated market leading high YOY growth for the past two years.  Already large and rapidly growing markets are good pockets to be in for the longevity of the toy market.  Makey Makey most relevant categories being Youth Electronics and perhaps Other Toys only over 8% of the same market in two categories that had negative growth either 2013-14 or 2014-15. The universal appeal of the Makey Makey might mean that these categories are totally irrelevant because it is, as we speak, redefining the toy industry categories—this is a very tough claim to bolster in media res.  Curious to see if either toy has won awards up to now, I found that Mecanno G15 –KS (the big brother toy) won an innovation award at CES 2015 in January. 
http://lastgadgetstanding.com/2015-recap/
https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2015/01/09/696358/10114914/en/Meccanoid-G15-KS-wows-the-crowd-takes-home-top-prize-at-Living-in-Digital-Times-Last-Gadget-Standing-Showdown-at-2015-International-CES-R.html
At CES, Meccanoid was also awarded the Geek Beat TV Robotics award as the editor's top pick in the robotics category. Off of TOTY main webpage under latest headlines is a press release regarding ‘smart connected play’ where SPIN MASTER the owner of Meccano the maker of the Meccanno G15 is a speaker; this demonstrates that SPIN MASTER is dialoguing with the industry and is respected as a thought-leader which speaks to the toys innovation claim. 
http://www.toyassociation.org/PressRoom2/News/2016_News/Digital%20Kids_Conference_To_Provide_Smart_Connected_Play_Insight_and_Advantages.aspx#.Vrv0nlgrLmE I searched for relevant media coverage or talks by the makers of Makey Makey at Joylabz, Eric Rosenbaum and Jay Silver
Jay Silver on Ted.com
https://www.ted.com/talks/jay_silver_hack_a_banana_make_a_keyboard?language=en
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xLLOsCSzuBY
Jay Silver speaker at makercon
http://makercon.com/new-york-2015/speakers/
CNN
http://www.cnn.com/2013/04/05/tech/innovation/jay-silver-makey/
They both seem to be getting the love of the tech startup crowd; less industry sponsored events etc. Relevant media coverage or talks by Spin Master owner of Meccano maker of Mecanoid G15
Ben Varadi, executive vice president and chief creative officer for Spin Master
http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2474738,00.asp
At CES
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZohGXwOtM_E
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/11356944/DRAFT-The-Meccanoid-a-build-your-own-robot-for-kids-unveiled-today.html
Robots & Baby Learning re: research Meccanoid development based on
http://www.popsci.com/robots-could-learn-same-way-babies-do Although Makey Makey marketing efforts were initially very organic and guerilla, including some minor snafus with post Kickstarter production ( Jay Silver spoke about early on contacting people who submitted oddball content and supplying them with more product for their weird inventions). Eventually, they hired Merge Design & Interactive to revamp their product packaging (as well as some other notable innovations) to make it more Target and Walmart friendly; see case study http://www.mergeworld.com/Our-Work/Makey-Makey. It is unclear whether they are managing any ongoing campaign for Joylabz. Still needing more convincing that Makey Makey is the industries salvation I went looking for articles that articulate the toy industries dilemma and predictions for what will save it. Found this Economist article http://www.economist.com/blogs/schumpeter/2013/09/toy-industry. Here are some excerpts and my analysis of how Makey Makey and G15 stack up to these industry directional forecasts.  “Standalone toys lack scale and versatility. Franchises that span multiple platforms—from cartoons to video games to films to physical toys—are a better bet. Hasbro caught the eye with their recent purchase of a 70% stake in the mobile gaming company, Backflip Studios, for $112 million. On August 7th the company announced a partnership with Ubisoft, a video game developer, aimed at bringing board games to the screen. The future, as Adrienne Appell of America’s Toy Industry Association says, is in “transmedia storytelling”. Hasbro’s strategy implies that a multi-platform model is now a prerequisite for success.” --Makey Makey: although not a franchise in any traditional sense like Star Wars or GI Joe, Makey Makey is not a standalone product, it can’t, it’s connected to the world to function; and furthermore, because every user’s creation has at least a possibility of being unique (live dog piano, water keyboard, etc.) this product intrinsically meshes well with existing social media sharing environments—it’s a non-ownable amourphous franchise that spans multiple platforms; it’s really a pioneer, something new, I just don’t know whether TOTY has the apparatus to appreciate this. It’s not the kind of franchise with comfortable, predictable, necessarily quantifiable metrics and it exists in an essentially chaotic system; you can imagine the gang at Joylabz having a good laugh at someone rigging up an animal turd keyboard—this is not the kind of creativity that the Barbie brand is comfortable with or capable of recognizing publicly.   --Meccanoid G15 is not standalone either; to my toy novice surprise, Meccano is probably the oldest toy maker in the world. See, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meccano and http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2474738,00.asp  "Meccano is an iconic global brand with a powerful DNA. It was founded in 1901 and has always been about being culturally relevant and creating toys that enable children and adults to build and stretch their imaginations," said Spin Master chief marketing officer Krista DiBerardino. [Spin Master chief marketing officer—wonder if they intended this pun lol]. 
Meccano meets The Economist’s franchise criteria in the traditional sense and could make for a great revitalization of the brand should this toy do well. Back to the article: “Toymakers can try to boost growth in other ways. One option is to reach out to new demographics. Big kids are often neglected. In Japan over 20-year-olds made up 23% of total sales in 2011. But only 3.5% of American toy buyers were buying for themselves last year. There is untapped potential here. Three years ago, David Beckham revealed that he had built the Taj Mahal out of Lego; sales of that kit spiked by 633% in just one day. --Makey Makey seems to be trying to do this; I’m not sold on the Makey Makey as an independent use toy for anything but a very precocious 13 year old up to adult; most of the user generated videos online feature adults or kids with adult guidance including school classes with teachers guiding kids on how to rig up and ground their devices, download the MIT open-source “Scratch” software etc. It still seems like there is a high degree of not-included knowledge and experience required in order to make Makey Makey makey.  --Meccanoid G15 targeted primarily boys 8+ and girls along and adult supervisors, so still has cross age group appeal, but much more a toy for young people.  Again in summary; I think the Makey Makey is awesome, my impediment for a higher percentage chance for winning is my understanding of TOTY’s organization and perspective and it’s ability to appreciate and measure (or anyone’s ability to measure) the innovative impact of the Makey Makey at this point in time.  Also, in the face of a hard to comprehend toy like Makey Makey it’s easy to gloss over the substantial merits of the Meccanoid G15. 
Economist article one more time: “Such strategies, though, are footnotes to the main challenge. Manufacturers must become cleverer at creating high-value, multimedia properties. Toy brands will prosper as entertainment brands. Fostering links with mobile platforms is the first step; commanding attention with compelling content and characters is the next. For the collectors of the future, it will not so much be the toys themselves but the stories they tell that captivate.” For captivating much of my attention these past two evenings I’m giving the Makey Makey a slight chance of winning adjustment, 5%.  G15 76%
Makey Makey 15%
Levitator 5%

I browsed through past years winner and compared some attributes. I considered what gender the toys appealed to (bonus for both), amazon rating, # of amazon reviews, price point (negative for more expensive), toys age range (bonus for broader/younger). Then I added some personal opinions about the innovation, accessibility and quality of the toys.

I looked at past winners and they seem to be weighted to appeal to both genders. A dinosaur one won in the past and I don't think they would select it again and same goes for the robot. *i-loom is creative, related to the recent surge in knitting and interest in doing things by hand
*i-loom would return the award to an artistic toy (similar to some earlier award winners), after robots have won the last 2 years
*Laser Maze has already been passed over several times, it could be their year
*Meccanoid is very expensive, gets mixed reviews from parents, and is similar to past award winners in a way that I believe harms it.  The MiPosaur also seems like a more accessible robot.
*The Jedi Force Levitator seems cheap and flimsy.  "Brand" name recognition (toys tied to a franchise) have not fared well in the contest in the past.

"The best toy that combines the most unique blend of innovative technology and play value for children today."
Cruis: Limited educational or play value
Loom: new tool for bracelets: Great for making bracelets but focus is narrow
Maze: Lasers! I like this idea but after all it's a maze for 2016. I'm not sure how long a kid will stay engaged with it.
Makey: This toy gets my highest rating because of the innovative and high play value for the money. It seems like the most flexible of the toys (in terms of different ways to play with it)
G15: I want one!! But this will be out of reach for a lot of younger kids and while a really cool robot, it's still another robot. Cool points for being able to program it though!
MiP: Very similar to last year's winner. I hope they don't do a repeat...
Jedi: This would be a lot of fun but not sure how well it would work outdoors. I think the value of play is a lower than Makey. But it has potential to spur very interesting questions for the curious kid... (BTW, I wish they wouldn't use the word magic and science on the same page....)

Reading the many comments from my gjp colleagues here in the net makes me adjust further on my initial lines of judgement. This question is a relative tricky one to me. The composition of the jury is clear to m, what however is not clear to me are the criteria on which ground the judgment will be made.  The below doesn't help me much further understanding the mechanics of decision findings. 
Does have anyone found the criteria on which the judgement is made?   Of course I am aware, that at least for the part of the public voters will by large possibly use guts feelings for their vote. http://www.toyawards.org/toyaward/The_Awards/toyaward/About_TOTY.aspx?hkey=c897f648-a33a-466b-b0e6-1278139ea024 WHAT CRITERIA MUST THE TOYS MEET?
All 2016 TOTY nominated products must be available at retail in the United States on or before November 17, 2015, and must have been introduced to the marketplace within the last two years. TIA requires verification that all TOTY finalist products have been reviewed by an independent third-party testing lab and comply with strict U.S. toy safety standards. You can view the complete Rules and Eligibility requirements here. HOW DID THESE FINALISTS GET CHOSEN?
The toys featured on this site are the 84 finalists that were chosen from more than 640 nominations.  Finalists were selected by the members of 12 Nominations Committees – one for each category – comprised of seven to 18 high-stature experts, including retail buyers, journalists, bloggers, trade media spokespersons, academics, and inventors/designers. CATEGORY VOTING
Five weighted ballots – one each for consumers (25%), mass and specialty retailers (40% combined), journalists and bloggers (20%), and members of the Toy Industry Association (15%) – were open from November 17, 2015 through January 17, 2016.  Winners were announced during a formal presentation ceremony on February 12, 2016.

MiP is quite innovative in terms of following human gesture commands and reacting to them. The high number is because of the ready usability of the toy and the striking charm of the use of technology in the toy.  G15 is innovative in letting the user teach the toy to do different things. And such a thing can be stimulating to the user. Makey is highly innovative because it lets the user be the innovator and the user's imagination makes a huge difference in how the toy is innovative enough. so it is more of a tool to the innovator, but certainly encouraging and stimulating to the user to think more and get creative which is a huge plus.

I think the decision of which toy is most innovative is extremely context dependent. If you purely think about where the idea for the toy came from, a prediction is far different than what the actual toy might be able to do differently than a previously invented toy. The greatest number of consumers does not necessarily mean that a toy is the most innovative. 
-flipsies: been around for years in different forms
-Makey Makey: you can essentially create any toy using any item, in a way this allows for innovation within innovation
-MiPosaur: toy sensory reaction has been created in many different forms prior to this toy

I looked at all the games and noted that the Meccanoid G15 has already won some major awards in 2015 so is a good bet to win this award as well. Awards won include the Swedish Innovation Toy of the Year. So it is the odds on favorite. But MiPosaur is a very interesting toy and a toy from the same company won Innovative Toy of the Year last year so it is certainly in the running. Jedi Force Levitator is interesting and a possibility but really, it's just electro-magnets. Makey Makey is interesting and looks like fun. A clever idea. It has an outside chance but that is a subjective judgment. Flipsie is a variation on toys I gave my kids 20 years ago - doesn't seem particularly innovative. iLoom is more innovative but really is just a loom with an online instruction manual - ho hum. And Lazer Maze just doesn't do it for me. I found it boring.

It occurs to me that another pleasant feature of the accursed Star Wars tie-in is that when the kid gets bored with it--which should happen fairly quickly, this toy being essentially a one-trick pony--it will not take up much space in the abandoned-toy locker, or the bottom drawer, or the dustbin. One wishes fervently for more fad toys like that; on that criterion, I am sorry we abandoned Pet Rocks.

Rearranging my percentages, because I was thinking this was for the overall Toy of the Year rather than the Innovative Toy of the Year. Oddly, the Innovative TOTY seems to be historically a less-sophisticated toy than the TOTY.  Sandy's House is out, because all previous winners (I checked back to 2005 only) in this category have some electronic component. The Jedi Levitator is lame and looks like children would  have a hard time getting it to work consistently. MiPosaur resembles the MiP that won last year too closely. iloom looks good, but a bracelet-making device won TOTY and Girls' TOTY in 2014. Innovative is a different category, but the fact that the toy is aimed primarily at girls, rather than a unisex toy, may limit it in this category. Previous winners have been unisex or unisex leaning toward male. Makey Makey is innovative. It had a Kickstarter campaign. It doesn't seem very accessible, though. Perhaps it's aimed at a niche market or older children, whereas the toys that win in Innovative tend to be simple in concept.  Meccanoid has already won a lot of awards. It seems complicated compared to past winners in this category, but the Toy Industry Association may feel left out, if they don't award the Meccanoid something, and this is the only category in which it's nominated. Laser Maze is interesting, but winners in the Innovative category have tended to be more hands-on, physical activities, not a board game. It's worth noting that there is NO overlap between the nominees in the Innovative category and any other category. So there is no case of "if the judges like it, they can vote for it in another category," which might diminish its chances in Innovative. Category judging is 25% consumers, 40% retailers, 20% journalists and bloggers, 15% members of the Toy Industry Association. So what would the retailers and journalists like? Meccanoid, because everybody else likes it and has given it an award.

Reducing iLoom based on research by Praedico (2014 winner was a bracelet making toy). Upping makey-makey. Past analysis:
Meccanoid and MiPosaur are more expensive and more defect-prone. Jedi is intriguing, but not sure it is intriguing beyond a couple weeks. Laser maze also sounds interesting and receives nice reviews, but again, not sure it can really hold the creative interest over time. I-Loom and Makey-makey appear to be the most creative and long-term entertaining. Slight edge to makey-makey based on innovation quality. I-Loom will have a strong following based on its "craft" foundations, so could carry the popular vote.

I probably shouldn't be in this question. There doesn't seem to be any pattern -or even logic- to which toy wins. See previous years' winners here: http://www.toyassociation.org/Events2/TOTY_Awards/2014_TOTY_Winners.aspx#.VnoR_jZk4lk Maybe there is some pattern to what doesn't win, though. Most of these toys seem like something children will play with a few times before getting bored. But that doesn't seem to bother the TOTY people. The Sandy's House & Cruiser seems like an average plastic toy that was included as a nod to political correctness. The Jedi Force Levitator is lame. The iloom and Laser Maze seem like toys that might sustain someone's interest. But I'm rating the iloom low, because the 2014 winner was a bracelet-making device. The iloom looks better, but, judging by previous years, TOTY does not like to repeat. I'm rating the Laser Maze high because it doesn't resemble previous years' winners. Meccanoid is rated highly, because it already has a lot of awards. Makey Makey is unusual, but I think not very accessible. I think it has a better chance in one of the other categories, like Innovative Toy or E-Connected. The MiPosaur is too similar to the toy that won last year, the Zoomer Dino. I had 5% left over to distribute, which I gave to the iloom and Makey Makey out of concern that I had under-rated them.
